title: Dianthus
text:
Dianthus is a <a href="genus">genus</a> of about 340 <a href="species">species</a> of <a href="flowering%20plant">flowering plant</a>s in the <a href="family%20%28biology%29">family</a> <a href="Caryophyllaceae">Caryophyllaceae</a>, <a href="native%20plant">native</a> mainly to Europe and Asia, with a few species in north Africa and in southern Africa, and one species ("D. repens") in arctic North America. Common names include carnation ("D. caryophyllus"), pink ("D. plumarius" and related species) and sweet william ("D. barbatus").
Description.
The species are mostly <a href="herbaceous%20plant">herbaceous</a> <a href="perennial%20plant">perennials</a>, a few are <a href="annual%20plant">annual</a> or <a href="biennial%20plant">biennial</a>, and some are low <a href="subshrub">subshrub</a>s with woody basal stems. The <a href="leaf">leaves</a> are opposite, simple, mostly linear and often strongly <a href="glaucous">glaucous</a> grey green to blue green. The <a href="flower">flower</a>s have five petals, typically with a <a href="Serration">frilled</a> or <a href="Pinking%20shears">pinked</a> margin, and are (in almost all species) pale to dark pink. One species, "D. knappii", has yellow flowers with a purple centre. Some species, particularly the perennial pinks, are noted for their strong spicy fragrance.

Etymology.
The name "Dianthus" is from the <a href="Ancient%20Greek">Greek</a> words δῖος "dios" ("of Zeus") and ἄνθος "anthos" ("flower"), and was cited by the Greek botanist <a href="Theophrastus">Theophrastus</a>. The color <a href="pink">pink</a> may be named after the flower, coming from the frilled edge of the flowers: the verb "to pink" dates from the 14th century and means "to decorate with a perforated or punched pattern". As is also demonstrated by the name of "<a href="pinking%20shears">pinking shears</a>", special scissors for cloth that create a zigzag or decorative edge that discourages fraying.
Alternatively, "pink" may be derived from the Dutch "pinksteren" alluding to the season of flowering . "Pinksteren" means "Pentecost " in Dutch. Thus the colour may be named from the flower rather than the flower from the colour.
Ecology.
"Dianthus" species are used as food plants by the <a href="larva">larva</a>e of some <a href="Lepidoptera">Lepidoptera</a> species including <a href="cabbage%20moth">cabbage moth</a>, <a href="double-striped%20pug">double-striped pug</a>, <a href="large%20yellow%20underwing">large yellow underwing</a> and <a href="lychnis%20%28moth%29">the lychnis</a>. Also three species of "<a href="Coleophora">Coleophora</a>" case-bearers feed exclusively on "Dianthus"; "C. dianthi", "C. dianthivora" and "C. musculella" (which feeds exclusively on "D. superbus").
Cultivation.
Since 1717, dianthus species have been extensively bred and <a href="Hybrid%20%28biology%29%23Hybrid%20plants">hybridised</a> to produce many thousands of <a href="cultivar">cultivar</a>s for garden use and <a href="floristry">floristry</a>, in all shades of white, pink, yellow and red, with a huge variety of flower shapes and markings. Over 100 varieties have gained the <a href="Royal%20Horticultural%20Society">Royal Horticultural Society</a>'s <a href="Award%20of%20Garden%20Merit">Award of Garden Merit</a> (see the <a href="List%20of%20Award%20of%20Garden%20Merit%20dianthus">List of Award of Garden Merit dianthus</a>).
Culture.
In the <a href="language%20of%20flowers">language of flowers</a>, pink "Dianthus" symbolize boldness.
"<a href="Dianthus%20gratianopolitanus">Dianthus gratianopolitanus</a>" – the Cheddar pink – was chosen as the <a href="County%20flowers%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">county flower</a> of <a href="Somerset">Somerset</a> in 2002 following a poll by the wild flora conservation charity <a href="Plantlife">Plantlife</a>. "<a href="Dianthus%20japonicus">Dianthus japonicus</a>" is the official flower of <a href="Hiratsuka">Hiratsuka</a>, Kanagawa, Japan.
